**Short answer:** If you are only holding a UK *provisional* licence (the one you use while you‚Äôre learning to drive) and you have **not** passed the practical test, you are **not allowed to drive alone** on public roads in England, Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland. The fact that you also have an ‚Äúinternational‚Äù licence does not automatically give you the right to drive by yourself unless that licence is a full, valid licence from a country that the UK recognises for resident drivers. If a police officer stops you and determines you are driving without a valid licence for the situation, you will most likely receive a **fixed‚Äëpenalty notice (fine and penalty points)** or be **summoned to court**. Arrest is rare for this specific offence unless it is combined with other serious breaches (e.g., driving under the influence, dangerous driving, no insurance, etc.). Below is a more detailed breakdown of the factors that matter, what could happen if you‚Äôre stopped, and what you should do next. --- ## 1. What ‚Äúinternational licence‚Äù usually means | Situation | What the document is | Does it let you drive alone in the UK? | |-----------|---------------------|----------------------------------------| | **Visitor** (you‚Äôre in the UK for <‚ÄØ12‚ÄØmonths) and you hold a **full, valid licence** from an EU/EEA country or a designated non‚ÄëEU country (e.g., Australia, Canada, Japan, South Korea, etc.) | *International Driving Permit (IDP)* **or** just the foreign licence itself (many countries don‚Äôt require an IDP). | **Yes**, you may drive as you would at home, provided the licence is still valid, you have appropriate insurance, and you are not a UK resident. | | **Resident** (you live in the UK and have been there >‚ÄØ12‚ÄØmonths) and you only have a **foreign licence** (no UK licence yet) | You can drive for up to **12‚ÄØmonths** after becoming resident, after which you must exchange the licence for a UK one (or pass the UK test). | **Yes**, for the first 12‚ÄØmonths only. After that you must have a UK licence. | | **Resident** and you have a **foreign licence that is not from a designated country** (e.g., many African, Asian, or South‚ÄëAmerican states) | You need to obtain a **UK provisional licence** and then pass the UK theory + practical tests before you can drive. | **No**, you cannot drive alone until you pass the UK test. | | **Resident** and you have a **UK provisional licence** (the ‚Äúlearner‚Äù licence) | You may drive **only** when accompanied by a qualified driver (‚â•‚ÄØ21‚ÄØyears old, has held a full UK licence for ‚â•‚ÄØ3‚ÄØyears) and you must display L‚Äëplates. | **No**, you cannot drive alone. | **Key point:** An ‚Äúinternational licence‚Äù (often an International Driving Permit) is **not a substitute** for a full UK licence if you are a UK resident who has failed the practical test. It only works as a *visitor* document or for the 12‚Äëmonth grace period after moving to the UK. --- ## 2. What the police can do if they stop you | Possible police action | Typical circumstances | Likely outcome | |------------------------|-----------------------|----------------| | **Issue a Fixed‚ÄëPenalty Notice (FPN)** | You are driving alone on a provisional licence, or you cannot produce a valid licence that authorises solo driving. | ¬£100 fine (or ¬£50 if paid within 21 days) + 3 penalty points on your licence. | | **Summon to a Magistrates‚Äô Court** | The officer believes the offence is more serious (e.g., you have no licence at all, you‚Äôre driving a vehicle you‚Äôre not insured for, or you have multiple offences). | Court may impose a higher fine, more points, or a short disqualification. | | **Arrest** | Rare for a simple ‚Äúdriving without a licence‚Äù offence, but possible if combined with:
‚Ä¢ Driving under the influence of alcohol/drugs
‚Ä¢ Dangerous or reckless driving
‚Ä¢ No insurance/road tax
‚Ä¢ Outstanding warrants or other criminal matters | You would be taken to a police station, charged, and could face a court trial. | | **Vehicle seizure** | No valid insurance or road tax, or the vehicle is being used in a way that breaches the law (e.g., unroadworthy). | Vehicle may be impounded; you‚Äôll have to pay release fees. | **In practice:** Most first‚Äëtime offenders caught driving alone on a provisional licence receive an FPN rather than being arrested. However, the police *can* arrest you if they think you pose a safety risk or if you have additional violations. --- ## 3. What the law actually says (UK) - **Road Traffic Act 1988, s. 87** ‚Äì It is an offence to drive a motor vehicle on a road without a valid licence authorising you to do so. - **The Highway Code, Rule 5** ‚Äì Learners must be accompanied by a qualified driver and display L‚Äëplates. - **DVLA guidance** ‚Äì A foreign licence is only valid for driving in the UK for up to 12 months after you become a resident, after which you must obtain a UK licence (or pass the UK test). If you have *only* a UK provisional licence and have **failed** the practical test, you **do not have a valid licence to drive alone**. The presence of an International Driving Permit or a foreign licence does **not** change that, unless you meet the visitor/12‚Äëmonth resident criteria described above. --- ## 4. What you should do right now 1. **Do NOT drive home alone.** The safest legal choice is to arrange alternative transport (taxi, rideshare, public transport, a friend/family member with a full licence, etc.). 2. **Check the exact status of your foreign licence.** - Is it a *full* licence (not a learner‚Äôs licence) from a country on the UK‚Äôs recognised list? - Have you been resident in the UK for more than 12‚ÄØmonths? - Is the licence still valid (not expired, not suspended)? 3. **If you are a resident and the foreign licence is still valid:** - You may drive for up to 12‚ÄØmonths after moving to the UK. - Make sure you have **valid insurance** that covers you driving the car. - Carry both the foreign licence *and* the International Driving Permit (if required) when you drive. 4. **If you are a resident and the foreign licence is *not* from a designated country, or you have been in the UK >‚ÄØ12‚ÄØmonths:** - You must obtain a **UK provisional licence** and **pass the UK practical test** before you can drive alone. - Until then, you can only drive with a qualified supervising driver. 5. **If you are a visitor (you‚Äôve been in the UK <‚ÄØ12‚ÄØmonths):** - Your foreign licence (or IDP) is fine for solo driving, provided you have insurance. - Keep the licence and any supporting documents (IDP, passport) with you. 6. **If you‚Äôre unsure, call the DVLA or a local Citizens Advice Bureau** for a quick clarification. They can confirm whether your specific foreign licence is accepted for solo driving. --- ## 5. What to expect if you *are* stopped | Situation | What to say to the officer | What to hand over | |-----------|----------------------------|-------------------| | You have a UK provisional licence only | ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a learner and I‚Äôm aware I need a supervising driver. I‚Äôm sorry, I made a mistake.‚Äù | Show your provisional licence. | | You have a foreign full licence + IDP | ‚ÄúI have a full licence from‚ÄØ[Country] and an International Driving Permit. I‚Äôm a resident for less than 12‚ÄØmonths.‚Äù | Show both documents, plus passport/visa to prove residency length. | | You have no licence at all | ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I don‚Äôt have a licence that allows me to drive alone.‚Äù | You may be given an FPN or a court summons. | **Tip:** Remain calm, be polite, and do not argue. If you receive a Fixed‚ÄëPenalty Notice, you can usually pay it online within 21‚ÄØdays for a reduced amount. If you think the notice is wrong (e.g., you *do* have a valid foreign licence), you can contest it in court, but you‚Äôll need evidence (photocopies of the licence, proof of residency dates, insurance policy, etc.). --- ## 6. Quick checklist before you ever get behind the wheel again | ‚úîÔ∏è | Item | |---|------| | **Licence status** ‚Äì Is it a full UK licence, a valid foreign licence, or just a provisional? | | **Residency length** ‚Äì <‚ÄØ12‚ÄØmonths as a visitor? >‚ÄØ12‚ÄØmonths as a resident? | | **Insurance** ‚Äì Does your policy cover you driving the specific vehicle with your current licence? | | **Vehicle tax & MOT** ‚Äì Is the car road‚Äëworthy and legally taxed? | | **Supervising driver** ‚Äì If you‚Äôre on a provisional, is a qualified driver with you and are L‚Äëplates displayed? | | **Documentation** ‚Äì Carry licence(s), IDP (if needed), insurance certificate, MOT/TAX documents. | If any of those boxes are red, arrange another way home and sort the paperwork before you drive again. --- ## 7. Bottom line - **No, you are unlikely to be *arrested* simply for driving alone on a provisional licence**, but you *will* be committing an offence and can be fined, receive penalty points, or be taken to court. - **If your foreign licence is a full, valid licence from a recognised country and you are still within the 12‚Äëmonth resident/visitor window, you *can* drive alone** (provided you have insurance). - **If you are a UK resident who has failed the practical test and only have a provisional licence, you must not drive alone**. Use a taxi, rideshare, public transport, or ask a qualified driver to accompany you. --- ### Need more help? - **DVLA (Driver & Vehicle Licensing Agency)** ‚Äì 0300‚ÄØ790‚ÄØ6801 or visit https://www.gov.uk/contact-the-dvla - **Citizens Advice** ‚Äì 0800‚ÄØ144‚ÄØ8848 or https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk - **Local police non‚Äëemergency line** ‚Äì 101 (for general queries about traffic stops).
